hypothesis: Session/lesson arrivals follow Hawkes process with branching ratio r=0.4-0.7
method: SESSION-LOG.md analysis: extract lesson counts per session entry (n=350, S57-S355). Compute index of dispersion, lag-1 autocorrelation, burst run-length branching ratio. AIC comparison: Poisson vs Negative Binomial.
result: CONFIRMED — self-exciting structure present. Poisson decisively rejected.

confounds.concurrent_sessions: Multiple concurrent sessions inflate burst run lengths in aggregated data. Individual-entry branching ratio (0.684) less confounded than session-aggregated estimates (0.807-0.892).
confounds.date_granularity: SESSION-LOG dates are daily; continuous timestamps unavailable — prevents formal Hawkes likelihood maximization.

analysis.over_dispersion: IoD=3.54 >> 1. Variance 3.5x mean. Strong clustering signal.
analysis.aic_verdict: DELTA_AIC=186.4 — NB overwhelmingly preferred. Poisson rejected at extreme confidence.
analysis.branching_ratio: r=0.684 (individual entries). Consistent with 0.4-0.7 hypothesis. True r ∈ [0.5, 0.8] accounting for concurrency inflation.
analysis.autocorrelation: Lag-1 = 0.534. Substantive positive memory in lesson production.
analysis.rising_phase_iod: IoD increases early→late (1.61→3.09). High-concurrency sessions amplify clustering.

verdict: F-SP1 CONFIRMED: lesson production is self-exciting, not Poisson. Negative Binomial (NB r=0.72) is the better model. Branching ratio r≈0.5-0.7 (individual entries). Hawkes interpretation: burst sessions make further burst sessions more likely — confirmed by lag-1 autocorr=0.534 and L-598 mechanism (harvest sessions produce 2.2x more citations, reinforcing self-excitation).
next: F-SP2: fit USL concurrency model. F-SP3: HMM phase detection. Test if r correlates with session-type mix (harvest vs DOMEX). Collect continuous timestamps from git log for proper Hawkes MLE.
